_prev_prog_3.Description: The RMP applicable process is the Boron Trifluoride storage and delivery system  (i.e., tube trailer to reactors).  BF3 is an acid catalyst used in two processes: Unit 20 and Unit 21.  The Process Hazardous Analysis for Unit 20 and Unit 21 have addressed BF3 and it's delivery system.  The BF3 tube trailer system is surrounded by a water deluge system as a control device for minimizing exposures.  In addition, Neville Chemical Company has extensive in-house policies, procedures (operations and maintenance) for the safe handling and use of Boron Trifluoride.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Neville Chemical Company and the Regulated Substances Handled



Neville Chemical Company is a world leader in the production of petroleum based hydrocarbon resins.  Our products are used in every day consumer applications such as printing inks, dyes, adhesives, mastics, pressure sensitive adhesive applications, rubber products and tires. As part of our production process, Neville Chemical Company uses a variety of petroleum based resin forming feedstocks that are blended and charged to production units. Petroleum based hydrocarbon resin production requires the use of various regulated chemicals. Of these regulated chemicals, only boron trifluoride gas (BF3), which is used as a catalyst, is subject to Risk Management Plan provisions.





Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Neville Chemical Company is committed to safe plant operations. The prevention of fires, explosions, and chemical releases is a priority.  Design, construction, and maintenance of processes and equipment are in accordance with established codes, standards, and practices.  All aspects of operations are reviewed periodically in order to minimize risk, and insure safe operation.   Incidents and near misses are reviewed, and corrective action taken when necessary.  All personnel involved in operating and maintaining processes and equipment are trained to carry out their assignments safely and effectively. 





General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention



Neville Chemical Company has several Plans and Programs in place for prevention, control and mitigation of accidental releases.  Neville has combined the following plans into a single emergency

response document called the Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) in accordance with EPA guidance.  The included plans are Preparedness, Prevention, and Contingency Plan (PPC), Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure Plan (SPCC), Allegheny County Hazardous Materials Off-Site Response Plan, Ma

rine Transportation-Related Facility Response Plan (MFRP), Facility Response Plan (FRP) and Emergency Response Management Plan (ERMP).  Neville Chemical Company also complies with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulations and the Coast Guard's security regulation in 33 CFR 105.





Five Year Accident History



Neville Chemical Company has not had a reportable accident or a reportable quantity release of boron trifluoride in the last 5 years.





Emergency Response Program



Neville Chemical Company's emergency response program is designed to promote coordination between facility personnel, emergency response personnel (i.e., fire departments, HAZMAT, police, etc.) and outside contractors.  Neville Chemical Company conducts drills and exercises at the facility, with outside personnel and agencies to improve coordination and ensure familiarity with our facility.   These drills and exercises also allow Neville Chemical Company to evaluate the capabilities of our outside resources.  In addition to drills and exercises, Neville Chemical Company also performs tabletop exercises, that on-occasion will involve our outside support resources.  



In conjunction with our boron trifluoride supplier, Neville Chemical Company periodcally reviews operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and our safety and health practices to identify where improvements can be made.  The supplier may also periodically audit the BF3 system and provide employee training.



Neville Chemical Company trains personnel to make sure they are familiar with their duties and responsibilities in accordance with established policies and procedures.  Neville Chemical Company has multiple systems to provide internal notifications and ensure communication among employees.  Systems include alarms, a public address system, and two-way radios. Public notification is handled by local government agencies and emergency radio/television broadcasts. 





Planned Changes to Improve Safety

    

Relief valves h

ave been removed from the BF3 trailer cylinders by the supplier. Removal of these devices reduces the possibility of leaks due to mechanical failure. 

 

Improvements to the BF3 manifold have been implemented. The overall number of valves in the system has been reduced by over 50%, diaphragm and bellows sealed valves have been installed as replacements where possible.  The amount of high pressure manifold piping has been significantly reduced, and the number or trailer hookup locations has been reduced from 3 to 1.  In addition, a second Remote Operated Valve (ROV) has been installed and tied in to the remotely located shutdown / deluge activation stations to isolate the process piping from the tube trailer connection piping.  Evaluation will continue, to determine if a suitable option can be found to replace ball valves used in isolation service.



Neville Chemical Company will continue to identify equipment and techniques for improving process safety.  The Company believes that our existing programs, policies, and operating procedures are designed to minimize the impact to employees, and the community in the event of a release.
